title: The Delta to Gamma Phase Transformation in Plutonium
content: Late in his career, Terry Mitchell began applying his keen crystallography acumen to the mechanisms of phase transformations in pure and alloyed plutonium (Pu). Of the six solid-solid phase transformations found in these materials, two have distinctly different forward and reverse transformation behavior: δ↔γ in pure plutonium and δ↔α′^ in stabilized δ-phase alloys. Both transformations are characterized by large volume changes, with ΔV δ→γ= ∼7% and ΔV δ→α′^= ∼20%. The δ→α′^ transformation typically occurs below -100 °C in alloys with less than ∼3 atomic % of a δ-phase stabilizer [1, 2]. The transformation from face-centered cubic δ-Pu to monoclinic α´ is martensitic and progresses until strain arrests further transformation at about 30 vol. % α′^. Upon heating, the reverse transformation is characterized by a large hysteresis (∼150 °C) and by a series of steps or bursts that are controlled by an autocatalytic and self-quenching phenemona [3]. Details of this transition were studied in detail using transmission electron microscopy by Zocco et al. [4], and Hirth et al. [5] used phase transformation modeling to reveal the crystallographic mechanisms.
